name: Puzzle Agent
description: When White House inquiries to the Scoggins Eraser Co. are answered only with curious puzzles, Nelson Tethers from the U.S. Department of Puzzle Research is sent on the case. The strange events in Scoggins will challenge every ounce of Tethers’ expertise, and possibly his very wits too, with brainteasers at every turn: mazes, logic...

reviews.review_text: First off, let me say: I come from a Professor Layton and Ace Attorney background. I live and breathe puzzles, but that's not to say that I'll take whatever I can get. My feelings towards the core factor of the game, puzzles, in Puzzle Agent are a bit mixed, but lean way more towards the positive end than the negative. Let's start with the negative. First off, some puzzle instructions are a bit difficult to understand or are surprisingly vague. However, this only happened to me a few times, and was far from the majority. Secondly, there were some jigsaw puzzles that, if you've played the Professor Layton games, are like the ones where you have to fit items into an area without them overlapping. There are a few here too, but it's odd in pieces automatically click together when placed correctly, and they STAY together, which greatly lessens the challenge. Those puzzles could definitely benefit from a better system, especially one where the general shape of objects were outlined and could snap together even if they weren't placed correctly. Other than that, I found the puzzles enjoyable. A few were quite easy, yes, but others took me a few tries and for some, I had to pull out a good ol' fashioned piece of paper and pen to plot it out Layton-style. Frankly, I don't understand how some people claim to have spent so many hints trying to solve them; I ended up using only 5 or 6 throughout the entire thing. There are 35 puzzles in all - I'll get to that in a moment - with 3 hints per puzzle, so with well over 100 hints you can imagine that 5 is far from a lot. To each their own, I suppose.  I've also seen people claim that the puzzles are placed erratically and interrupt the story, but honestly? I've felt that numerable times playing Professor Layton. That is the consequence of puzzle games. They WILL interrupt the story if you choose to do the non-plot-important puzzles, and even some of the necessary ones. That's just how it is. However, especially during the climax of the game, the puzzles begin to weave into the story a bit more cleanly than before, and in my experience, are appropriately some of the easier ones, so you can get through to the ending quicker without having to spend half an hour on one puzzle. I think the game's biggest downfall for me, personally, is LENGTH. It is simply too short. Like I said before, there are only 35 puzzles. The average Professor Layton has over 100. It only took me a few hours to get through the entire game, and it leaves you on a VERY unsatisfying cliffhanger ending. Granted, it does pick up again in the sequel, but it literally goes right from the climax to ending in the first, with practically no conclusion. It was surprising, to say the least. Once the credits popped up I said 'that's it?' out loud. I was genuinely surprised. It's a bit cheap to me to separate these two games when it certainly feels like it should be only one, twice-as-long game, but I have no played the second as of yet, so I have no info on how the story of that unfolds or if it is completely related. At the very least, there should be a package including both games so it can be one long, consecutive playthrough without people having to wait until they get money (i.e., me) to finish a story that should have been wrapped up already. The art style, characters, storyline (it's one of the 'out there' kind of stories, but it's strangely fun at the same time despite its absurdity), and audio are superb. Music matches the in-game events wonderfully, but don't distract during a puzzle, as it should. I enjoyed the protagonist and the supporting cast, and their voice acting was wonderful as well.  I fully recommend this game to new players of puzzle games, or veterans of the Professor Layton series. It may be a bit clunkier than the latter in some respects, but it is definitely worth a good playthrough. You're bound to get some enjoyment out of it.  EDIT: Oops, I believe there are actually about 37 puzzles in the game; I had missed two during my first playthrough. Also, I'm going to add that I am currently on my third playthrough of the game, and I still enjoy it. I'm going to add that the game is somewhat fast-paced, or at least the cutscenes are, so even though puzzles will be extraordinarily easy to solve, I'd recommend multiple plays because I've noticed several things that I didn't recognize the first time around, buuut perhaps that was because I was intentionally reading into things because I was analyzing Nelson Tether's character a bit. In any case, definitely worth another look at if you enjoy playing it. One final point I'd like to bring up is that of the somewhat 'rating' system assigned to the puzzles. Depending on how many wrong answers you give (resulting in the anger of millions of taxpayers) and how many hints you use, you get assigned a rating of sorts. Perhaps unintentionally, but hilariously, there is some pressure on the player to answer correctly on the first go, so you can expect to unconsciously triple-check your answers before you submit. It's really not something to fret about - at least to me, it's more humorous than anything else.

Puzzle Agent is an amusing puzzle game in the vein of the Professor Layton series on the Nintendo DS, where a narrative is played out interspersed with (seemingly random and often unrelated) visual puzzles which the player must solve. The puzzles are fairly easy (with one or two exceptions which are QUITE obtuse), and shouldn't cause most people much trouble. Furthermore, it's worth noting that the game is rather short, and the story ends rather abruptly (to be continued in the sequel). It's not a 'to be continued,' mind you, but....well, you'll see.  The story is....weird. It is to be experienced. It's kinda the point, and is rather surreal (in a literal sense). I found it amusing, but my sense of humor is nicely warped, so that's not too surprising. It might not be for everyone, but I'd recommend it.

Puzzle agent is a light adventure/puzzle game with a lot of charm and some imaginative puzzles, based upon the work by Graham Annable (which I was entirely unfamiliar with when I played the game)   Graphics & Sound  Puzzle agent has a very distinct art style, one that I guess is a bit of a love it or hate it kind of deal. It's very consistent though, everything looks like it belongs in the world, and nothing looks out of place. Personally, I found the game to be nice looking, in its own peculiar way. The sound design also works well with what the game tries to be. The voice actors do a good job at portraying the different characters, and while there are no Oscar winning performances here, it works well. The voice acting also helps lend the game a lot of personality, which makes it memorable for more than just its puzzles.   Story & setting  In Puzzle Agent you play as agent Nelson Tethers, who works at the US department of Puzzle research. There are trouble in the small town of Scoggins and their eraser factory, which supplies erasers to the White House. Thus your job is of utmost importance to the safety of the country. Scoggins is a peculiar place. Everyone is obsessed with puzzles, and not only that, everyone is also a bit Norwegian. Your job is to find out what is going on, and why there are pointy red hats seen everywhere. To make matters worse, the entire city is out of chewing gums, something that agent Tethers need in order to focus on his puzzles. This ties in directly with the games hint system, if you spend some of the gum you have in you've picked up you get a hint for whatever puzzle you're working on.   Gameplay  Gameplay is mostly straight forward. You click on objects like in a point & click adventure game, gather talk to people, and quite often you're given a puzzle. These puzzles don't fit in as well with the world as something in say Syberia or The Longest Journey, but are their own self contained little entities. This does allow the game designers to constantly mix things up with new and interesting puzzles, but at the expense of some immersion. If you've ever played a Professor Layton game, you'll feel right at home here, the puzzles are handled in a similar way. And the vast majority of the puzzles are fun to solve.  Puzzle Agent is not a particularly lengthy game. The game can easily be beaten in less than 3h if you're comfortable with solving logical puzzles.   Final thoughts  Puzzle agent is an excellent little puzzle game with a really fun story, and some well thought out puzzles. At a base price of 5€, it's hard to not recommend this game, despite its short length.

Puzzle Agent is a casual little 3-4 hour puzzle game that remains reasonably entertaining throughout, though it's a tepid sort of entertaining that I can't really recommend.  The puzzles themselves aren't very well scaled in difficulty, with both easy and trickier ones mixed together throughout, though none of them could be called challenging. Certain puzzles reminded me of SAT logic questions back from my high school days, so I suppose it takes a certain kind of person to enjoy them. I recommend using a notepad, since many puzzles with a logical process of elimination or others with more visual elements are made easier this way. The puzzles are also graphically unappealing - the in-game story / adventure sections give way to single static screens for each puzzle, without any moving elements (uncontrolled by the player at least) and an overall board game-type look.  The biggest problem though is that the puzzle design just isn't very good. A few puzzles have a set of 'rules' that must be followed to successfully complete them. Unfortunately, certain rules are vague and open to different interpretations, and others are entirely ommitted (unintentionally) and must be discovered by submitting an incorrect answer. An example of this would be a sequence of platform movements to build a bridge - ommitted rules include 'all platforms move at the same time', and 'platforms stop moving once they reach a destination'. I know that's a bit hard to visualize if you haven't played the game, but I felt like I should give an example.  In at least two specific puzzles I can remember, I submitted absolutely correct answers that followed every rule provided by the game, but were not the solutions the game was looking for. Those are disappointing oversights for a game built around only a handful of puzzles (just over 30). And there are 4 or 5 puzzles that involve assembling objects like a jigsaw - these can all be easily and quickly cheated without any effort by dragging a piece around the screen until it snaps together with another, and repeating until the puzzle builds itself.  Puzzle Agent's shortcomings in puzzle-solving are offset by the fact that there is no real penalty for wrong answers. They reduce your score, but perfect scores are not rewarded by anything at all, so no one save the most addictive completionists will care.  What elevates the game from 'bad' is the story, which I found charming and mysterious. I'm a sucker for the Mountain Town with a Secret kind of vibe. The voice acting isn't better than okay, and the game also struggles with its tone - it jumps from dark and mysterious to silly and unbelievable - but it's still sort of fun.  (At one point you distract someone pointing a gun at you by throwing a crossword puzzle at him, and he just can't help himself from filling out a crossword puzzle, can he? It's looney, I guess.)  Fair warning though: the game ends on a cliffhanger without revealing its mysteries, so it feels more like Episode 1 to the sequel's Episode 2 rather than a self-contained full story.  Another warning: Puzzle Agent 2 does not work on any Mac OSX released since mid-2013. This is not a problem that is likely to be fixed, so if you're strictly a Mac user, DO NOT invest any time into this game, since you will be left without the story's conclusion. This is another example of the Steam Store's lack of quality control, and Mac's terrible habit of compatibility issues with each new OSX release. Who's to blame but everybody I suppose?  So in short, there's nothing really *bad* about this game, but it's not great. Definitely not worth a full-price purchase, but if picked up on mega sale, it makes for a reasonable distraction when you have nothing to do.   5/10
I loved this one! Some puzzles are very unfair and badly explained, but they're nice overall. And the story is great and very compelling.

Good game if you like puzzles or if you ever wanted to live the life of an FBI agent of 'The US department of puzzle research'. Funny story and challenging puzzles. About 3 hours of gameplay for this price is worth it if you ask me.  10/10 want to be a FBI agent of the US department of puzzle research again.

This is a great puzzle game. If you ever played Professor Layton on the Nintendo DS you know what to expect. It's a point-and-click puzzle adventure. There are puzzles that are part of the story and there are puzzles that are well, just puzzles really. Great fun ! The game keeps track of the number of hints you used and mistakes you made and gives you a score based on that. It doesn't really do anything in the end, it's just there for fun. There are 37 puzzles in total, but not all of those are related to the story. And the story... well, if you like Twin Peaks, I'm pretty sure you'll like the story of this episode. The graphics are stylish and everything looks clean and the voice acting is well done. Highly recommended. Can't wait for episode 2.  [Rating: 90/100]

The Puzzles and atmosphere of this game is great, and can be very suspensful despite it's literaly sketchy art style. But it ends way too soon. Less than 2 hours to complete, and just as things are starting to get interesting, BOOm game's over, no real resolution, and you're left with massive amount of unanswered questions.

This is like a mini Professor Layton game.  About 35 -ish puzzles exist in the game and the rest is well-written dialogue with a quirky mystery-type short story.  I would recommend it as a gift to a puzzle-loving friend or for younger audiences. Hindsight being 20/20, I wouldn't have bought it for myself, even on sale. I don't see myself replaying it.

I fully enjoyed this game. The puzzles were legitimately challenging, and the unsettling mystery element is fantastic. However, I felt that the game was a bit short- but for the price, it's to be expected. It has quite a bit of replay value, as I feel as if most people may miss a few things the first playthrough. The ending leaves a bit to be desired, but that's what sequels are for! My main issue is that a lot of the puzzles' instructions weren't very clear, although this seems to be common judging from other reviews. All in all, it is a great game despite these minor flaws, and I wholeheartedly recommend it!

Puzzle Agent is not the most well known Telltale game out there. I got it because I bought the Telltale Game Collection and didn't in the beginning care about this game. It was all about Borderlands and Game of Thrones, but I gave it a shot because I liked the comic book graphics.   -------------------------------(May be spoilers, BUT this happens very early!)-------------------  It starts of with seing the main character, Nelson Tethers sitting by his desk and solving crosswords and eating some bubblegum. He yawns and falls asleep. He wakes up by something walking towards him.    He wakes up and sees a big astronaut in front of him. The astronaut takes the crosswords and writes something on it. Nelson Tethers looks frightened and confused as he watches the astronaut. The astronaut stops writing and stands up. The astronaut starts to slowly take of his helmet. Nelson Tethers screams with fear as he is shown what is inside of the astronaut.   He wakes up screaming in fear and rips his crosswords apart, but calms down quickly. Looks around and there is noone in sight. He lookes down to see that there is some writing on his crosswords. He decides to solve the puzzle! A little quest thingy pops up and it says 'Nelson Thethers' crossword puzzle has been ripped to bits... but is there something written on it? Reconstruct it to find out.' When you are done with the puzzle you can see that it says    'SCOGGINS'    . You suddenly get a call. You get an assignment! You are going to solve an accident that happened in the town    Scoggins    !  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  This is the kind of mysterious humor that often occurs in this game and this is a typical puzzle. There are very many puzzles and some of them are actually really hard. Great voice actors and sound. Lovely comic book graphics. Really mysterious and thrilling story with alot of 'Wait what?'.  On the down side : It can be very repetitive. Just going around and solving puzzles isn't maybe the funniest thing to do according to some people.   Lovely game that isn't well known. Definitely worth 1€ as it is right now when I'm writing this.   8/10 pepparkakor!
37 puzzles to solve, great story full of mysteries and even scares! Love the picture jigsaws. Played with boyfriend all the way through. He is much better at solving puzzles than me. Emm...  8/10

Do you remember the games you used to play in computer lab at school in elementary? It has the distinct nostalgic feeling of that for sure with the giant mouse icon and the hand drawn looking graphics. Agent Tethers makes for a unique lead character for sure, and the story is unheard of and strange, but engaging and funny. You play an FBI agent, puzzle division, how fun is that?! If you enjoy adventure style point and click puzzle games, you'll devour this one. It's fantastic and challenging. Your brain will thank you for trying this game.

What I expected was a series of point-and-click adventures. What I wasn't expecting was the creepy but immersive missing-person mystery taking place in a disturbed little town. Another pleasant surprise is a peak inside the life of a FBI puzzle researcher. The puzzles can be unclear in their directions at times and the game does come to an abrupt end, but the ending is still satisfying because an important reveal. There are no steam achievements but there are achievements in the sequel, which I very much look forward to playing.
Think Professor Layton meets Fargo.   Great atmosphere, art style, puzzles and music.
If you enjoy silly things and solving puzzles this is a good game.
The puzzles are perhaps a little derivitive, but thery're hard enough.  Fun story, atmosphere, and voice acting.
very nice puzzle game, too short and you need to buy the second part for see the story continue... I have to say that the end was a little.... meee, for the rest nice game.

This game stands strong among the likes of professor Layton and other such story dirven puzzle games. The puzzles themself are more straightforward than the previously mentioned and rely less on riddles and alternate meaning. The story itself is quite dark and interesting and goes along with Graham Annable's art perfectly. I personally am eagerly awaiting the sequal.

Not as good as either of its primary inspirations - the hit DS series Professor Layton and the Coen Brothers movie Fargo - but still a worthwhile couple hours.   As a side note, you'd really think Telltale would have better writers, since writing is basically all their games have as a selling point.

Basically Professor Layton in gameplay and execution. However, it is much more simple and the puzzles aren't nearly as tricky. It's got pretty good voice acting. The art style and animation messed with my eyes sometimes though. It's fairly short and can be beaten in only a couple of hours. The Voice acting was pretty good and this game was surprisingly spooky for a couple of moments.  Freaking gnomes.
Plays exactly how the title reads; solve puzzles as a (quirky) agent. Full of odd and funny characters that are well-defined by superb voice acting! 8/8

The story is good, although short, and then the ending is bad. the puzzles vary between ok but easy and frustrating because of poor explanations/no ability to make notes/having to constantly click to another screen for rules. I struggled on a few puzzles because of difficulty but most of the struggle was just frustration. Others aren't hard but purely tedium - eg connecting the images together, when you put them in the right place they snap together so you can't go wrong but it's very hard to actually see how they should connect together often so you just move stuff around hoping they'll work. A couple puzzles have too many steps but you can't make notes or draw or anything which is a pain. A few have confusing explanations and eg the one revolving around patrons looking like food I couldn't work out which a couple of people were supposed to look like. I had some fun and for the price it's not bad but kind of a frustrating experience.
This game is ♥♥♥♥ing crazy.  And that's awesome.  Please buy it.

No... just no  I've made a mistake. I finished this game in about 3 hours and I felt unsatisfied at the end. There's also no replay value since the puzzles don't change and the story isn't all that captivating.   I should have bought a crate key

I usually love puzzle games, and I enjoy this cartoonist's art. But I'm afraid the two don't necessarily go together all that well. I encountered several puzzles that were hard to understand and solve because of the abstract, cartoon art style.

I am finding the puzzles to be too easy. I've solved about 6 so far, and none have taken more than a few minutes. The dialogue is starting to get boring to me as I realize that the actual puzzle part of the game (the reason I bought this) is not that fun. I have started clicking to skip through the dialogue scenes. I would only possibly recommend this game for middle age kids.

great atmosphere, the whole experience leaves you wanting to know more. some of the puzzles are obtuse and aren't clearly explained, but overall it's a good variety. definitely worth the 0.99 I picked it up for
Game and puzzles look great, Though there's an unused potential for a more nonlinear side quests on a map.

I'm not usually a fan of point and click adventure games, but I am a fan of puzzle games. To me, this is the perfect point and click adventure game because most of the 'hunting for clues' part is simply replaced with puzzles and the rest is very straightforward. I loved this game and I look forward to picking up its sequel the next time it goes on sale.

I received everything I expected from 'Nelson Tethers: Puzzle Agent', and also a few more 'surprises' that I wasn't expecting at all. There are a great mix of problems to solve throughout this adventure (even though some puzzles have nothing to do with the game's progress), and I found myself paying close attention to the intriguing story. The plot is fairly linear, but it was still super fun learning what was going to happen next. This game left me disturbingly pleased using its eerie and unique aesthetic.
Bad puzzle game, worst money I've ever spent. DON'T BUY THIS!!!

Will NOT run on the OS system! The game just simply won't run! You might be able to hear the music playing in the background, but all you get is pixelated jumble and have to force quit. It's a problem for a lot of users, check the discussion forum out. The developer is not doing anything about it, and Steam support is copy and pasting useless replies. All in all terrible experience to a game that I was really looking forward to. Someone need to fix it NOW!!!
Too much fluff and animation, not enough puzzles. I finished it in less than two hours, I'm fairly certain my 10 yr old cousin could do it even quicker.
Buy it on sale, but buy it. I couldn't get over the atmosphere, and the jump scares, and the bureaucracy.
this game is fun & hilarious. always a good combo.

Pretty fun game but the core mechanic of the game: solving puzzles are pretty poorly designed with the Puzzles being vague. As far as puzzle games go, it's a C+ while a Professor Layton game may be considered a A+.  Verdict: There are better puzzle games out there to try. If you play this game, just play it for the storyline and stumble your way through the puzzles.
Good for when you want to pass the time away through a calmer game than something like a shooter or action game.

Professor Layton-type puzzling game with a dark, sinister edge belied by the game's cute visuals. As a puzzle game, it's solid. As a story out of equal parts Twin Peaks, Fargo, and X-Files, it's surprisingly gripping.
Imagine Professor Layton, but not dry, and the puzzles are explained better as well as mechanics as chewing gum, as opposed to the eplanation-free hint coins of Professor Layton.

Great little game that keeps your brainscells from dying of boredom. Story ends cliffhanger-ish, pointing to the sequel with both hands. I guess one has to like the style and overall mood of the game, but I have to say that I had loads of fun and am looking forward to playing Puzzle Agent 2 once I find the time.

I can get the game going alright but there are no instructions on how to play. I cannot find anyway to save the game as it proceeds or because I need to leave it at any random point. I can only quit by pressing Command/Q but there is no offer of saving before I leave. I really don't need to have to spend time finding out very basic stuff like this when it should e entirely obvious. This is the second game I have bought from Steam which has fundamental flaws. 'Dream' is another which will not even start, a known problems apparently but nothing is being done about it. £13 down the drain.
Kind of an odd mix of Professor Layton, Twin Peaks and Fargo.
If you like solving puzzles, this is highly recommended! Don't know what's up with gnomes though. Valve games love gnomes too.

If you like puzzle games, you will fing this one mediocre. It's not a bad game, but it's not a great one eather. Still I was interested to play trough the game and that is why I recommend it. I recommend it for people who play puzzle games or point and click adventure games. Not many games no play in the genre, give this game a try if you can find it on a discount. Not worth 5 euro imo. 2 euro tops.
Quick short, but fun game. Humorous at times, with puzzles that at times can be confusing by lack of instruction. Found it entertaining though and some of the puzzles really make you think.

The easiest way to describe Puzzle Agent is 'Professor Layton' mashed with 'The X-Files'. Explore Scoggins, Minnesota, talking to the townfolk and solving puzzles, trying to discover the truth about an explosion at the local eraser factory. What caused the explosion? Why is the factory locked up? Where did the foreman go?  It's a fun little story with some puzzles to solve. Just be prepared to pick up the sequel if you want the conclusion to the story.

This is a great little puzzle game. I bought it not expecting much and was delightfully surprised by its quirky charm. It has many little puzzles which are just hard enough to keep you wanting to play and easy enough to keep you from throwing your keyboard. The storyline alone was enough to have made me want to keep playing. An absolute gem and a definite recommend to puzzle lovers.
With a bizarre plot, challenging puzzles, and quirky midwestern humor Puzzle Agent is a hidden gem. My only gripe is that some of the puzzles tend to come out of nowhere diffficulty wise.
Nice puzzles, good story, great humour and lovely graphics. Loved it.

Great puzzle game with a good storyline. While not the longest puzzle game you'll find, it makes up for it with some challenging puzzles and a few side-puzzles.  Worth a shot, especially to get through the story of an overlooked FBI agent investigating a strange town!

This game is a very light and casual diversion you can dip into for short periods. It's basically a series of small puzzles with a little bit of story around it. The puzzles are mostly very simple, with a few slightly more challenging ones. Nothing mentally strenuous though. The story gameplay is point-and-click adventure style.  It has a very basic art/animation style, but it's playful in its own way, and the voice acting is reasonably good. The plot is a bit weird and ends leaving quite a bit unexplained.

Interesting story, but terrible puzzles. I have completed 9 puzzles so far. 6 of the puzzles either had the wrong answer as the correct answer or there was not enough information provided to complete the puzzle without looking up the answer online.

Love the art style and the way the game presents itself. Characters are superb and story is weird. Puzzles are decent, I liked most of them but the ones where you had to fit stuff onto a space were just.. kinda bad. Also as a non native english speaker I found the descriptions of some puzzles confusing, but thats just me.  Would recommend, especially if you enjoy professor layton style of games because Puzzle Agent pretty much copies the format.

I really enjoyed my time with this game, and that quite suprized me!  This game has a good sense of humor, a great art style, a great cast of charicters, and it doesn't overstay it's welcome. Beat the game in two sittings, and was happy with the whole experience.  Two quick notes though: The puzzles are occasionally frustrating, not because they are perticularly difficult, but because a few of them are explained in a strange way.   If you plan on playing this game on mac, be aware that the sequel does not work on the mac, even though on first glace it looks like it does. I want to know what happens in Puzzle Agent 2, but I may have to look up a playthough on youtube, which isn't the same as just playing the game.

One word describes this game best: Charming. The characters, the humor, the sound design and the story all factor towards creating a really charming game. Though the puzzles are mostly not too difficult and the playing time of roughly 4 hours aren't too impressive, believe me, this doesn't ruin the game at all. It's like an intelligent christmas movie you like going back to every year.

Appears to have much more going on to it than just a mere puzzle game. Another side to a much larger story in the format of a game (in puzzles)?  All in all, I had fun with the puzzles. Didn't need to chew nearly as much gum as I expected to in order to kick ♥♥♥.

★★★½* This game is a linear point and click storyline with puzzles of various difficulties to solve. Unfortuately, it crashes on Mac often and in some places it crashes every time.   *Recommended if crash issues become resolved

If you love puzzles, maybe...I love challenges, puzzles and story, but found this game to have more fillers than content...If you got it on the cheap, maybe, but otherwise I cannot recommend this game.
Thanks Ross!

This game and it's successor (Puzzle Agent 2) feel like a mixture of Fargo, Professor Layton and a charming graphic novel.   If you like puzzles and comedic, gloomy, criminal stories then give this game a try. Short and entertaining, the ideal thing for the evening or a rainy weekend :-)
Simply great puzzle game with awesome athmosphere.
The puzzles range from tricky to ridiculously easy. Overall the game plot, art style, and humour were enjoyable. Worth a play, especially if playing with someone else. :-)

Game is good like all telltale games. Story line is good but puzzles isn't that hard. Only thing I didn't like is that game is too short (3h-4h). But I realy recomend to buy this game because I enjoyed that few h of gameplay.

Quite a fun game, with great puzzles. They won't have you reaching for the walkthrough very often, due to a hint system that nudges you in the right direction without revealing everything, which is always a bonus. There are also some very unsettling moments which gave me goosebumps.
This game is if Stanley Kubrick and David Lynch made Professor Layton

Puzzle agent is a fun little puzzle game with several types of puzzles to solve. No crosswords or find a words here. The story of the game is pretty good, but a little more detail in spots would have been nice to really flesh out the story. I enjoyed the game, and look forward to playing Puzzle Agent 2.
Thank you TELLTALE games. This was a very fun and refreshing game to play. I liked the Comedic Background.
Short but fun game, if you can get it for cheap I highly ecommend it! Some of the puzzles are simple, but others are very complex, it's a bit varied. Expect to be immersed and surprised!
Very fun, though some of the puzzles are not obvious. Great story and fun characters, though.

Puzzle Agent offers a set of puzzles which are interleaved into a story. Though it is completely linear, doesn't change, and not based on your actions or performance, it has all the features of a good story and it keeps your attention for a couple hours this game would take to finish.  I've enjoyed puzzles so much; they are complicated enough to be a challenge and simple enough to be solved without a pen and paper.  The sad note is that I put this game on shelf right after completion. Zero replayability.

It's a telltale game, but instead of following clues and carrying objects around, you solve a wide variety of puzzles. Great fun to while away the boredom if you have time to kill. (Also fun to play with your better half)
Do you want your brain to hurt from a crap load of super confusing puzzles? If so, then avoid this game at all costs! If not, then good luck...
Did this in one run. Really amazing approach to the Professor Layton concept, and set in a very Silent Hill inspired world. Challenging, and very fun.

Ahhh, Puzzle Agent. Follow the story of this one guy who has to solve a bunch of puzzles for whatever frickin' reason. It's really fun if you like the whole Professor Layton style puzzle things. I got like 3 hours out of it, and it was worth it, in my opinion. If you're mega poor it might not be. Or if you don't enjoy puzzles. Still.
Good story with fun puzzles. No real complaints. Only thing really puzzling is why you haven't bought this game yet.

Puzzle Agent is a game similar to Professor Layton, in that you travel from area to area solving clever and sometimes brain-breaking puzzles toward a greater end. Puzzle Agent, however, does have its own distinct flavor - a unique artistic and animation style, interesting characters, and a subtle, haunting soundtrack. The soundtrack is actually what sticks out most to me; it's almost Silent Hill-esque, making the Puzzle Agent experience all the more surreal and disturbing. Don't let its appearance fool you. Puzzle Agent is definitely a creepy game.
A fun and occasionally humorous little diversion. Puzzles range constantly from obvious to a vague sense of 'maybe this is right?'. Those Gnomes sure are creepy though.

This game is wonderfully fun and extremely challenging at the same time. If you like point and click adventures with puzzles that require you to think more than you usually would, grab this game. The artwork is fantastic as well.

It has great puzzles and an interesting, thrilling and sometimes funny story. What more can you ask for? Except for maybe more of the same, since it's a tad short. But it's also quite original! So I give it a 8.5/10.  Get it!  P.S.: This game is also available for iPhone/iPod touch and iPad. Having the iPhone version and the PC/Mac version, I've found it to run smoother on the PC. But the touch version can be more comfortable to some.

It's a fun little story. Actually can be pretty creepy at times even though the game-play keeps you at arms length from the action at all times. The puzzles are a lot of fun and rarely annoyingly difficult. I can only think of a couple puzzles that I just could not get without help. If you enjoy Point and Click adventures, I say go for it.

Puzzle Agent was ok. The protagonist is the top puzzle solver at the FBI and he's gotta find out why there was an explosion at a eraser factory in a remote mid-west town. The gameplay is all puzzle box format. There are minor, minor adventure elements to the game but, the story progresses by solving brain teasers. The puzzles themselves were mostly easy. Only around 10% posed any real challenge. There's a running joke where every time the solution for a puzzle is offered for verification, it shows an exorbitant running tab for how many taxpayer dollers were used to investigate the explosion. The game took around 3-4 hours to finish. This game is really geared for the younger crowd.
Interesting puzzles and story keeps you hooked.

Recommended without hesitation even though it features a few irritating behaviours like unskippable sequences and broken puzzles. Puzzle Agent is a very likeable point & click adventure with a mystery twist. The game is very well produced with a coherent and engaging story which might make you feel somewhat guilty towards the end.   Features of Note

This and it's sequel are collections of puzzles wrapped in a short story similar to the Professor Layton series. They contain maybe a couple dozen puzzles each. The story and dialog aren't anything special but it does get pretty weird.
Fun game, pity it is so short.
Neat!

Puzzles are overly simplistic and easy. Game is very short (3-4 hours). Ending is... not an ending. However, the minimalistic art style works very well and the game has great atmosphere. I would love to play a full length adventure game (whether puzzle oriented or not) in this style. I also like the click to highlight interaction spots mechanic which avoids the tedium of the old adventure pixel hunt.
Suprising cool story and puzzle game. With an enchanting Fargo like feel this games is absolutely a joy to play.

This is a nice little point-and-click puzzle game. The art style and sound is nice. It's somewhat comical. Puzzles range from very easy to 'HUH?!?'. The user interface could be better, including how your puzzle results are presented. Playtime around 3 hours. You can retry the puzzles if you wish, for a little more.  I got this game as part of a cheap humble bundle deal. I'd suggest getting it on sale if you're into this type of games and want a short, entertaining game.

Quick pros and cons list:   Pros    Amusing, diverse characters   Interesting and creepy storyline   Diverse puzzles    Cons    Vague and ambiguous ending   Some minor jump scares   Too-simple gameplay   Graphics can be poor sometimes   Puzzle Agent is a decidedly weird game to play. To put it simply, imagine an episode of  Twin Peaks  where Dale Cooper is replaced with a slightly neurotic puzzle enthusiast, the residents of the town are all the Log Lady in various disguises, and the demonic creatures of the night are   evil garden gnomes  .

Pros - Dry humor - Creepy story - Suspensful music  Cons - Sometimes vague puzzle rules - Have to go away from a puzzle to see it's rules - No ability to skip a puzzle if you really can't figure it out - Hints are often unhelpful or   I couldn't find it in me to be intersted enough in the suspense of the story and how it was going to end to put up with the cons of the game.
Couldn't get past the 2nd puzzle due to well known bug on my Mac.
Good. Short. Worth $5. No more.
Nice puzzles, lacking story
I love this game. I didn't expect to be spooked by a puzzle game, but Telltale is obviously right for the job. Great atmosphere, creepy story, and challenging puzzles.

Meh. It's got some good brain teasers in it, but the animation is slow, and I mean slow. The point and click adventure elements were a real turn off for me. I found myself just clicking through conversations because they are slow and the individual staements I can read in a second, and then you're waiting for the speaker to catch up to you. Should have forgone the voice acting and just went with text bubbles. Would have saved them a lot of time and effort, because I wasn't listening to any of it. Then you have to sit through slow animations, which is sad because the animation is not anything spectacular. The artwork is cute, but kind of looks like a blown out tattoo on larger, HD screens. For a dollar or two this might be fun to play on a road trip when you're stuck in the car, otherwise there are better puzzle games out there. I would suggest it for little kids, but the puzzles are going to be too difficult for some. The only thing I thought was itneresting about the game was the laughable amount of money the FBI is spending on solving puzzles. Basically if you get it right on the first try it only costs the tax payers a meager $75000. That's a pretty funny comment on government spending. Not worth it for tha tone joke though.
Not a review, just a fav

The second puzzle is bugged and unplayable. Apparently a number of puzzles in this game have the same problem and this has been an issue since 2010. Really disappointing that TellTale's done nothing to fix it.

The art style and atmosphere alone makes this little story puzzler WELL worth your time. The art style really reminds me of some old cartoons I watched as a kid but in HD. I really enjoyed this little 3 hour game, and I definitely recommend it if your one of those huge nostalgia buffs like me lol.  If your looking at this game for purely puzzle difficulty, you might not find what your looking for in this game. Still a great little, point and click adventure though.
I loved this game, while short the humor in it is amazing. I think it is definitely worth 5 dollars.

This is a very cool game. It is a bit old so the animation isn't much to shake a stick at but the best aspects of later Telltale narrative games (great characters, streamlined player interaction) are evident in this early effort. The puzzles are a bit easy at first but get more difficult as it goes along. If you like Professor Layton or any other puzzle-related point-and-click adventure games then you will like Puzzle Agent and its sequel.

Bought this game on a recommendation and played it in a night. It's a very quick, charming game, with an intriguing plot. Though the plot is somewhat whimsical, laying somewhere between Twin Peaks and Gravity Falls, it often does feel quite heavy and is always driving. The plot threads reveal themselves nicely, and the atmosphere, sometimes humorous and sometimes ominous, is well delivered.   However, I do think the game lacks resolution and feels like it drops a lot of what is happening very suddenly. Perhaps this is all addressed in the sequel? Still, I can't quite decide if the lack of resolution is affective or disaffecting.  Furthermore, this game is basically fully animated and voice acted with a unique look and feel. The acting is mostly good going on great. The choppy, sketchy animation style is tonally versatile and a pleasure to look at - furthermore the occasional moments of typical Paradox 3d visuals fit quite nicely.  Perhaps most importantly, the puzzles are often very fun, but sometimes initially ambiguously worded. They do ramp up in difficulty from simplistic to quite challenging, but I never found the puzzles annoying.  So, overall, very fun, incredibly intriguing game, much in the vein of Myst. Definitely worth it.

Great little game. Puzzles ranging from very easy to very complex, but always solvable if you hold your mouth right. The comical story line keeps you interested, and drives you to purchase the follow up game.  Good for about 4-5 hours of goodness.

Funny little puzzle adventure, even some quest were reapeated and the story is not rly satisfying. But if you want to solve some puzzles, you like the hand drawn graphic style and you do not have problems with english language, take your time and play it. It took me around 6 hours and now im starting Puzzle Agent 2 ;)
Awesome story!  Awesome puzzles!  A very gorgeous game! Buy it!

This Game almost hit my expectations, after i read all the reviews before i played the game.  Difficulty:  2 of the 37 puzzles i solved were a little bit more challenging than all the others. The others were just 'too easy'. And yeah, i played all Myst Games, so i know what i'm talking about. If you want to have 3 hours of light entertainment (more storytelling and some surprise moments    That red gnomes are creepy!    than puzzling) than this is for you. Other than i thought i really liked the game graphics, but that's only my personal taste. I'm looking pleased forward to play Puzzle Agent 2. But i dont think the games are worth the full price.  Pros: - light entertainment - nice graphics - all voices are crisp clear and gives evryone a personality - the puzzles are logical - nice atmosphere  Cons: - way too short - easy puzzles - gums are too easy to find - a few puzzles had no clear instructions (more like try and error, but prevented me getting a perfect score) - the end came too soon, i didnt expected it, the puzzles didnt get harder or gave me the feeling of a 'beat the endboss-challenge) - no replay value
Fargo and HP Lovecraft mixed into a sureal cartoon universe. It's an outstanding game with good puzzels, a good hint system and an awesome story! I couldn't suggest this game enough! :)

Good premise, faulty execution.  Yes, the plot is rather silly, and serves mainly to tie the puzzles together. But since you bought a game called Puzzle Agent, presumably you're mainly interested in the puzzles, so that's okay.  Where the game fails is that too many of the puzzles are poorly described: either the rules, or the goals aren't clear. For instance, in one puzzle, you have to place tiles to form a path through a forest, to a goal, without meeting any monsters. Except that it's not enough that there be a monster-free path to the goal: none of the branches may lead to a monster, something that the game doesn't make clear. In another, you have terminals on a circuit board, and have to form an electrical connection between them. After banging my head against this puzzle for half an hour, I bought hints and learned that the electrical circuits already printed on the board were purely for decoration, and not part of the puzzle at all.  With some additional playtesting, and tweaking of the puzzle descriptions, the game could be much better.

Playing this game is like solving one of those kids puzzle magazines while watching a silly detective cartoon. Puzzles are not very original or hard and there is a built in hint system, so there is no chance you will ever get stuck. The story, characters and music are all well done, and the game was very fun. My only real complaint would be the puzzle interface, especially the part after you submit the solution, that takes you out of the game world a bit.  There are some scary moments during the game, and if you like that kind of stuff, go to YouTube and check out videos by the author (grickle) like 'The Hidden People' or 'The Webb'.

Cool story with funny moments and the art style and animation are charming. Definitely recommend. It's fairly short, I messed around with puzzle free-play at the end for a while, I would say the actual length is like 2-3 hours.

I love this game so much! The protagonist is very funny and entertaining as it is the story. The veil of mistery over Scoggins, Minnesota basically beg you to be uncovered and will keep you fixed on the screen till the end of the game. *Whispers* And don't forget the puzzles, funny and well made *blink* *blink*
Great story, good humor. The puzzles are doable without a walkthrough.
One of the few games that I have enjoyed in the last few years.

It's Professor Layton meets Fargo. The game is roughly 3 hours long and contains roughly 40 puzzles total making for a short game, but with a very good story behind it. It is a point and click but does not contain any puzzles 'out in the world' like the usual point and click. Contains a very interesting clicking mechanic which will reveal places that can be clicked on within an area where you clicked, which keeps the game to the story and puzzles.
One of Telltale's first games. Love the charming art style and story, puzzles are fairly standard logic puzzles but not too hard. Good sense of humor as well.

Puzzles are challenging. Game offers plenty of humourous and absurd moments pictured by fine artwork of Graham Annable. If you're into logic/puzzle games - give it a try.   By the way - don't go to Scoggins (Minnesota). There's ABSOLUTELY NOTHING to see there. Nothing, ok?
